Description text: Three storied brick with stuccoed dressings in an “Italianate” style. c.1850. Three bays with the  central bay being formed by a double Venetian style tripartite window. Dentilled eaves with ornamented shaped rustication at the sides of the building. Three string-courses running between the windows. The second-floor windows with curved hoods. The first floor windows are pedimented with elaborately ornamented consoles or brackets supporting the pediments. Modern shop front. The facade is in the style of the local architect Pearson Bellamy, but there is no documentary evidence that supports an attribution to him.
Name: 255 High Street

Statement of Significance: If Roman, a rare asset. If post-medieval boundary stone (re-set), one of seven in the city. If a milestone, unique in the city.
Name: Milestone, 111 High Street

Road or Street Name: Corner Upper Long Leys Road & Mill Road

Description text:
Unaltered Arts & Crafts Garden Suburb house of 1919 in a row of 4; rendered front, steep pitched roof with tall chimneys, windows immediately below the eaves. Original 1919 door and fenestration, possible unaltered render colour. The front garden embraces the Garden Suburb principles of hedges without fences or walls.

The only surviving example retaining the original doors and windows of 113 houses built 1919-20 in the first and only phase of the development of Swanpool Garden Suburb. Exceptionally well maintained and preserved, known locally to be the home of a professional painter & decorator.

Number 33 and its immediate neighbours in the row of 4 represent archetypal examples of the architectural style of the 1919 building phase. The group of 4 present a unique contrast of number 33 with 31, 35 & 37 which display typical subsequent changes in fenestration, doors and colour.
Statement of Significance:
Swanpool Garden Suburb is the only example of garden city suburb development in Lincolnshire. Adherent to the principles of the Tudor Walters Report of 1918, designed in the Arts & Crafts style by architects Thompson, Hennell & James of London. Colonel J.S.Ruston was the catalyst for the foundation of the Swanpool Co-operative Housing Society Ltd. in 1919 to provide affordable housing for industrial workers.

Number 33, immediate neighbours (31,35 & 37) are exemplars of the first phase of development.

Swanpool Garden Suburb is a rare example of an early 20th century City suburb of social housing built by private enterprise, built 1919-20 in the Arts & Crafts style with steep-pitched roofs, tall chimneys and rendered frontages.

Although Swanpool Garden Suburb enjoys statutory protection as Conservation Area 11, 33 Hartsholme Drive is the only remaining example of the 113 original houses to retain the primary fenestration, door and unpainted rendered front and serves as the exemplar for the original scheme.
Name: 33 Hartsholme Drive
